September 5, 1924.
Monthly Progress Report
August 1924.
The Surgeon-General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Division of Scientific Research,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to forward herewith monthly progress report
of malaria investigations conducted during the month of August, 1924,
under the direction of this office.

Field Laboratory, Crowley, Louisiana: Personne; - Special Expert M. A.
Barber, Assoc. San. Eng. W. H. W. Komp and Technical Asst. Theo. B.
Hayne.

Activities at the Crowley Laboratory consisted of: (1) Continuation of
experiments on conditions affecting growth of Anopheline larvae; (2)
Continuation of larvicide experiments; (3) Continuation of experiments
with mosquito repellents; (4) Continuation of plantation surveys for
Anopheline intensity and malaria prevalence; (Blood specimens examined
for malaria parasites sent in by physicians twelve, all negative; col-
lected on plantations 240, eleven positive P. vivax, seven positive P.
falc.; (6) Study of incidence of Anopheles - collected imago stage
3,961, A. quadrimaculatus 47.1%, A. crucians 52.9%; bred out 64, A.
quadrimaculatus 31%, A. crucians 69%; all larvae collected in water
which has now become salt proved to be A. crucians.

Field Laboratory: Personnel - A. A. Surgeon Wn. A. Krauss and Micros-
copist Retha Kitchens.

501 blood smears were examined for malaria parasites, of which 450
were sent in locally for diagnosis, of these 41 were positive P. vivax
and 58 positive P. falc; 28 blood specimens from Aiken County, South
Carolina, showed one positive P. vivax, one positive P. falc.; 23 blood
specimens sent in by Tennessee State Board of Health showed three
positive P. vivax, four positive P. falc.
Field Laboratory, Savannah, Georgia: Personnel - Tech. Asst. Bruce Mayne.

Activities at this laboratory consisted of: (1) Observations of Anopheles
incidence, a definite predominance of A. quadrimaculatus now noted along
the Savannah River, in other sections of Chatham County quads appeared
where not previously observed; (2) Meagre numbers of larvae and pupae obs-
erved, continued activity of Gambusia constantly noted; Sixty blood

specimens sent in for diagnosis examined during the first two
weeks in August, all negative; (4) Malaria mosquito survey made
of Okefenoke Swamp during the last two weeks in August at request
of the State Health Officer, special report.

Epidemiological Studies of Malaria: Personnel - Asst. Surg. K. F.
Maxcy.

Dr. Maxcy's activities consisted of: (1) Study of typhus-like dis-
ease; (2) Tabulation of malaria school survey data collected last
winter; (3) Investigation of malaria focus at Teasley's Mill, Mont-
gomery County, where three cases of malaria hematuria with two
deaths occurred within past three weeks; (4) Instructing Dr. Makin,
Epidemiologist of the Texas State Board of Health.

Impounded Waters in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Epidemiologist
T. H. D. Griffitts, Asst. San. Eng. E. H. Gage and Microscopist Ethel
Barrier.

Dr. Griffitts (Alabama), activities consisted of: (1) Inspection of
River Falls Power Company Pond, Covington County, three adult mos-
quitoes found in two dwellings and one barn inspected; (2) Inspec-
tion of Forest Lake, Tuscaloosa County, recommendations for correc-
tion made to State Health Officer; (3) Inspection of Golden Bridge
Pond, Houston & Dale Counties, mosquito breeding being controlled
by oil applied under pressure; (4) Inspection of Dothan City Power
Project Geneva, Houston and Dale Counties, clearing of basin begun
several months ago, quinine being sold at wholesale prices during
preliminary construction around this project; (5) Inspection of
Mitchell Reservoir, Coosa River, Anopheles breeding in very limited
numbers.

Mr. Gage (South Carolina) activities consisted of: (1) Obsercations
continued of Anopheles prevalence and distribution in Horse Creek
Valley, Aiken County, marked increase in numbers of A. quadrimacu-
latus observed, but A. crucians still the predominating type; (2)
Malaria History sensus continued in this locality, blood speci-
mens collected for examination.

At the request of the State Health Officer of Alabama Microscopist
Ethel Barrier was ordered to Florence, Alabama, to investigate mal-
aria prevalence among the population within mosquito flight range
of the Muscle Shoals impounded water project. Miss Barrier visited
290 families, consisting of 1682 individuals from whom she collected
1225 blood smears, to be examined for malaria parasites.

Major Drainage in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Assoc. San. Eng.
A. W. Fuchs.

Mr. Fuchs' activities consisted of: (1) Observations of Anopheles
production and physical conditions in drainage ditches of Critten-
den County, Arkansas, New Madrid and Dunklin Counties, Missouri
and Bolivar County, Mississippi; (2) Inspection of ditch maintenance
in Mississippi County, Arkansas and Bolivar County, Mississippi.
Monthly Progress Report
September 5, 1924.

Cooperative Fish Studies: Samuel F. Hildebrand of the Bureau of
Fisheries continued his cooperative fish control investigations
around Augusta, Georgia, conditions influencing Gambusia density
are being studied, a series of sixteen experiments is now under
way. At the request of the Medical Officer in Charge and the
State Health Officer of Alabama, Mr. Hildebrand and Mr. LePrince
made an inspection of the fish hatcheries constructed in con-
nection with the Cherokee Bluffs impounded water project, re-
commendations were made for the construction of additional hat-
cheries and proper maintenance of the old ones.

Rural Malaria Investigations: Personnel - Asst. San. Eng. J.C. Carter,
A.A. Surg. C. P. Coogle, Assoc. San. Eng. L. M. Fisher, Assoc. San.
Eng. A. W. Fuchs, Asst. San. Eng. J. G. Foster, Asst. San. Eng. H.N.
Old, Asst. San. Eng. F. R. Shaw and Surgeon L. L. Williams, Jr.

Mr. Carter (Alabama), activities consisted of: (1) Investigation
of severe malaria outbreak at Clayhatchie, Geneva County, 27% of
population affected, quinine placed in rural stores to be sold at
cost - this method of control to be checked against a community
five miles distant where quinine was distributed free; (2) Instruction
in mosquito control given to cotton mill operators in Bullock County;
(3) Investigation of malaria outbreak at Teasley's Mill, Montgomery
County, house-to-house survey of 17 families made, of 80 people ques-
tioned 40 report having had malaria this season.

Mr. Old (Georgia) activities consisted of: continued observations of
mosquito production in Chatham County, 34 out houses searched for
adult mosquitoes, 110 A. crucians and 174 A. quadrimaculatus collect-
ed; ten dwellimgs searched inside, no crucians and one quad found,
relative increase of A. quadrimaculatus continues.

Mr. Shaw (Louisiana), activities consisted of: (1) Encouraging exten-
sive drainage around Patterson, St. Mary's Parish, Louisiana, and en-
couraging control of mosquito breeding in 585 cisterns in Patterson;
(2) Study of relative efficiency of Gambusia, cat fish and turtles
in control of mosquito production in cisterns; (3) Studies of ditching
by dynamite in St. Mary's Parish; (4) Screening studies continued
in Tangipahoa Parish.

Mr. Fuchs (Missouri), activities consisted of: malaria and mosquito
surveys in Dunklin and New Madrid Counties; effort being made to de-
termine amount of Anopheles production and locate malaria foci in
these counties.

Dr. Coogle and Mr. Foster (Mississippi) continued study of housing
conditions in relation to malaria in Leflore County, Mississippi;
Twenty tenant houses have been completely screened and exact cost
data od screening is being prepared; 26 houses have been treated
with creosote oil, 135 inspections of houses were made, 119 blood

specimens were collected and examined, of which 24 were found posi-
tive, nine P. vivax and 15 P. falc.; spleen examinations of the
sa,e group gave 17 enlarged spleens.

Mr. Fisher (South Carolina), activities consisted of: (1) Continued
observation of fish control of mosquito production in pond near
Columbia; (2) Screening observations continued in 25 houses at
Sellars, Marion County, screened last spring; no cases of malaria
have occurred this summer although last year fifteen cases occurred
in these same houses; (3) Study of value of school malaria census
card continued in Marion, Beaufort and Charleston Counties.

(Dr. Williams (Virginia), activities consisted of; Continuation of
study of rural malaria control methods in Henrico, James City, Isle
of Wight, Nansemond,. Accomac and Northampton Counties; during August
6600 feet of drainage was completed, mosquito breeding in three
ponds was controlled; 40 houses were screened and mosquito produc-
tion was controlled by oiling in seven localities; mosquito control
by drainage continued in Nansemond County, in each instance results
being checked by history index; screening program continued in Isle
of Wight County, all malaria cases reported are visited and surveys
made to determine probable source of infection; both screening and
drainage programs continued in Accomac County; house-to-house survey
made around impounded power reservoir in Halifax County; all seven
Counties have completed spot maps of malaria cases; types of mosqui-
to breeding in seven counties show very few changes, although A.
quadrimaculatus are appearing in localities which have been free
heretofore.

Conferences and Inspections: Inspection of Muscle Shoals Project by
Medical Officer in Charge and Senior Sanitary Engineer J.A. LePrince;
Inspection of housing studies in Leflore County Mississippi by Medical
Officer in Charge, Dr. M. A. Barber and Senior Sanitary Engineer J.A.
LePrince.

Expenditures: During the month of August approximately $4,885.15
was exponded from the Malaria Allotment in connection with field
investigations of malaria.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
